<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/brief.md</path>
<content lines="1-17">
 1 | # Project Brief: Chimera Protocol
 2 | 
 3 | 2D Pixel Art Action-RPG/Metroidvania with Horror/Mature themes built in Godot 4.5.
 4 | 
 5 | ## Core Vision
 6 | A parasitic entity escapes containment in "Sector 9" bio-lab, dynamically mutating body parts to traverse and combat. Non-linear "Memento" narrative reveals the player IS the monster.
 7 | 
 8 | ## Goals
 9 | - Fluid mutation-based traversal (Chimera System)
10 | - One-handed control scheme for accessibility
11 | - Tight Metroidvania progression gating
12 | - Mature themes integrated into gameplay mechanics
13 | 
14 | ## Scope
15 | - Single-player experience
16 | - Pixel art at 640x360 native resolution
17 | - Target platforms: PC (Linux/Windows)
</content>
</file>
<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/product.md</path>
<content lines="1-33">
 1 | # Product Context: Chimera Protocol
 2 | 
 3 | ## Project Overview
 4 | 
 5 | "Chimera Protocol" is a 2D Pixel Art Action-RPG/Metroidvania with a Mature/Horror aesthetic. Set in an abandoned bio-lab ("Sector 9"), the player controls a parasitic entity capable of dynamic body mutation. The game targets a niche adult audience with mechanics that intertwine horror, action, and mature themes.
 6 | 
 7 | ## Core Experience
 8 | 
 9 | - **Atmosphere**: Dark, Visceral, Tech-Horror (Inspired by Carrion, Parasite In City).
10 | - **Key Mechanic**: "Chimera System" — The protagonist dynamically mutates body parts using absorbed DNA, consuming Genetic Essence as a resource.
11 | - **Movement**: Hybrid system combining traditional Platforming (Human form) and specialized traversal (Mutations: Wall Climb, Glide, Liquid Pass-through).
12 | - **Narrative Style**: Non-linear "Memento" structure — story revealed through Memory Fragments as the player discovers they ARE the monster.
13 | 
14 | ## Core Loop (Metroidvania Progression)
15 | 
16 | 1. **Explore**: Traverse the lab in Human Form (agile but weak). Encounter obstacles (Organic Webbing, High Walls, Toxic Gas).
17 | 2. **Hunt**: Defeat Alpha Specimens (Boss/Elite) guarding specific sectors.
18 | 3. **Assimilate**: Absorb their DNA. Gain a permanent Mutation (e.g., Mantis Claws to cut webs).
19 | 4. **Backtrack**: Return to previous areas to bypass obstacles using the new Mutation.
20 | 5. **Unlock Memory**: Finding specific "Trigger Objects" restores flashbacks, revealing narrative truth.
21 | 
22 | ## Target Audience
23 | 
24 | - **Primary**: Adult gamers (18+) seeking horror-action with mature themes.
25 | - **Secondary**: Metroidvania enthusiasts who appreciate tight mechanics and exploration.
26 | - **Niche Appeal**: Mechanics designed for "one-handed play" accessibility.
27 | 
28 | ## Strategic Goals
29 | 
30 | - **Quality First**: Prioritize code quality and game feel over development speed.
31 | - **Scalable Architecture**: Apply Backend engineering principles (Modularity, Separation of Concerns) to Game Development.
32 | - **Game Feel**: Achieve fluid movement transitions between gravity-based and mutation-specific modes.
33 | - **Narrative Integration**: Ensure gameplay mechanics reinforce the horror of self-discovery.
</content>
</file>
<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/context.md</path>

 1 | # Active Context
 2 | 
 3 | ## Current Focus
 4 | 
 5 | - Integrating Game Design Document (GDD) into memory bank.
 6 | - Filling gaps identified in memory bank review.

 8 | ## Recent Changes
 9 | 
10 | - Added `gameDesign.md` with detailed narrative, Chimera System, and mature mechanics.
11 | - Updated `product.md` with core loop, target audience, and Metroidvania progression.
12 | - Updated `system.md` with expanded collision layers (hitbox/hurtbox) and data schemas (MutationResource, EssenceConfig, HostArchetypeResource).
13 | - Updated `tech.md` with specific rendering settings and one-handed input system.
14 | - Updated `progress.md` with detailed milestones for Chimera System and Extraction mechanics.
15 | 
16 | ## Active Decisions
17 | 
18 | - Renamed "Symbiosis-bonding" to "Chimera System" for clarity.
19 | - Adopted Genetic Essence as the core resource system.
20 | - Defined Host Taxonomy: Fodder, Specialist, Alpha categories.
21 | - Confirmed 640x360 resolution with canvas_items stretch mode.
22 | 
23 | ## Next Steps
24 | 
25 | - Begin implementation of Movement System (Human Form base).
26 | - Prototype Genetic Essence drain/restore loop.
27 | - Document Save/Load and Audio design approach.

<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/architecture.md</path>
<content lines="1-161">
  1 | # System Patterns
  2 | 
  3 | ## Architecture Style
  4 | 
  5 | Adopting **Composition over Inheritance** (Entity-Component approach).
  6 | 
  7 | ### 1. Folder Structure (Feature-Based)
  8 | 
  9 | ```
 10 | res://src/
 11 |   ├── characters/   # Player, Enemies scenes & scripts
 12 |   ├── components/   # Reusable Logic (HealthComponent, HitboxComponent, ParasiteController)
 13 |   ├── resources/    # Data Definitions (Stats, Skills - .tres files)
 14 |   ├── levels/       # Maps and TileSets
 15 |   └── autoload/     # Global Singletons (SignalBus, GameManager)
 16 | ```
 17 | 
 18 | ### 2. Design Patterns
 19 | 
 20 | - **State Machine**: Essential for managing complex Player and AI behaviors. Avoid nested if/else.
 21 | - **Signal Bus**: Use a Singleton `SignalBus` for decoupled communication between nodes (Observer Pattern). Similar to Node.js EventEmitter.
 22 | - **Resources as Data**: Use `.tres` files for defining static data (Stats, Skill parameters) instead of hard-coding in scripts.
 23 | 
 24 | ## Technical Standards
 25 | 
 26 | ### Naming Conventions
 27 | 
 28 | - **Folders/Files**: `snake_case` (e.g., `health_component.gd`).
 29 | - **Classes/Types**: `PascalCase` (e.g., `class_name HealthComponent`).
 30 | - **Variables/Functions**: `snake_case`.
 31 | - **Constants**: `SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE`.
 32 | 
 33 | ### Typing
 34 | 
 35 | Strict Static Typing is **MANDATORY** in GDScript (e.g., `var health: int = 100`) to leverage autocomplete and prevent runtime errors.
 36 | 
 37 | ### Physics
 38 | 
 39 | - Logic must reside in `_physics_process(delta)`.
 40 | - Use `move_and_slide()` for `CharacterBody2D`.
 41 | 
 42 | ### Collision Layer Convention
 43 | 
 44 | - **Layer 1 (Bit 0)**: World (Main Walls/Floors).
 45 | - **Layer 2 (Bit 1)**: Vents/Backlayer (Hidden paths).
 46 | - **Layer 3 (Bit 2)**: Player Body.
 47 | - **Layer 4 (Bit 3)**: Enemy Bodies.
 48 | - **Layer 5 (Bit 4)**: Interactables (Items, Switches).
 49 | - **Layer 6 (Bit 5)**: Player Hitbox (Attack detection).
 50 | - **Layer 7 (Bit 6)**: Enemy Hitbox (Attack detection).
 51 | - **Layer 8 (Bit 7)**: Hurtbox (Damage reception).
 52 | - **Layer 9 (Bit 8)**: Hazards (Environmental damage).
 53 | - **Layer 10 (Bit 9)**: Extraction Zone (Grapple/Finisher triggers).
 54 | 
 55 | ## Data Schemas (Resource Definitions)
 56 | 
 57 | ### MutationResource (`.tres`)
 58 | 
 59 | Defines each mutation's properties for the Chimera System.
 60 | 
 61 | ```gdscript
 62 | class_name MutationResource extends Resource
 63 | 
 64 | @export var id: StringName
 65 | @export var display_name: String
 66 | @export var source_enemy: StringName  # Alpha that drops this mutation
 67 | @export var traversal_ability: StringName  # e.g., "wall_climb", "glide"
 68 | @export var combat_ability: StringName  # e.g., "web_trap", "air_dash"
 69 | @export var essence_cost_per_second: float = 5.0
 70 | @export var icon: Texture2D
 71 | ```
 72 | 
 73 | ### EssenceConfig (Genetic Essence System)
 74 | 
 75 | ```gdscript
 76 | class_name EssenceConfig extends Resource
 77 | 
 78 | @export var max_essence: float = 100.0
 79 | @export var passive_drain_rate: float = 1.0  # Per second in mutated form
 80 | @export var extraction_restore: float = 100.0  # Full restore on finisher
 81 | @export var kill_drop_amount: float = 10.0  # Small drop on normal kill
 82 | @export var weakened_threshold: float = 0.0  # Triggers Human revert
 83 | ```
 84 | 
 85 | ### HostArchetypeResource (Enemy Taxonomy)
 86 | 
 87 | ```gdscript
 88 | class_name HostArchetypeResource extends Resource
 89 | 
 90 | @export var id: StringName
 91 | @export var category: StringName  # "fodder", "specialist", "alpha"
 92 | @export var essence_yield: float
 93 | @export var extraction_required: bool = false  # Specialists/Alphas need extraction
 94 | @export var mutation_drop: MutationResource  # null for fodder
 95 | @export var base_stats: Dictionary  # health, damage, speed
 96 | ```
 97 | 
 98 | ## Animation Pipeline
 99 | 
100 | ### AnimationTree Structure
101 | 
102 | Player uses `AnimationTree` with `AnimationNodeStateMachine` for form-based transitions.
103 | 
104 | ```
105 | PlayerAnimationTree
106 | ├── HumanStateMachine (Default)
107 | │   ├── idle
108 | │   ├── run
109 | │   ├── jump_rise / jump_fall
110 | │   ├── slide
111 | │   ├── dash
112 | │   └── weakened_idle (Essence depleted)
113 | ├── SpiderStateMachine
114 | │   ├── wall_idle / wall_climb
115 | │   ├── ceiling_hang
116 | │   └── web_attack
117 | ├── BehemothStateMachine
118 | │   ├── heavy_idle / heavy_walk
119 | │   ├── charge
120 | │   └── ground_pound
121 | ├── LiquidStateMachine
122 | │   ├── blob_idle
123 | │   ├── flow (through grates)
124 | │   └── reform
125 | ├── AvianStateMachine
126 | │   ├── glide
127 | │   ├── air_dash
128 | │   └── dive_attack
129 | └── SharedTransitions
130 |     ├── transform_to_X (0.3s blend)
131 |     ├── extraction_finisher (1.0s, i-frames)
132 |     └── death / game_over
133 | ```
134 | 
135 | ### Animation Naming Convention
136 | 
137 | `{form}_{action}_{direction?}` — e.g., `human_run`, `spider_wall_climb_up`, `avian_glide_left`
138 | 
139 | ### Transition Rules
140 | 
141 | | From | To | Trigger | Blend Time |
142 | |------|----|---------|-----------:|
143 | | Any Human | Spider | Jump + Wall contact | 0.15s |
144 | | Any Human | Behemoth | Hold Shift + Down | 0.3s |
145 | | Any Human | Liquid | Enter Vent/Grate | 0.2s |
146 | | Any Human | Avian | Double Jump (air) | 0.1s |
147 | | Any Mutation | Human | Essence = 0 (forced) | 0.5s |
148 | | Any | Extraction | Interact on stunned | 0.0s (immediate) |
149 | 
150 | ### I-Frame Windows
151 | 
152 | - **Dash**: 0.1s at start
153 | - **Slide**: 0.05s at start
154 | - **Transformation**: Full duration (0.15-0.3s)
155 | - **Extraction Finisher**: Full duration (1.0s)
156 | 
157 | ### Sprite Sheet Standards
158 | 
159 | - **Frame Size**: 64x64 pixels per frame (Human), 96x96 (Behemoth), 48x48 (Liquid)
160 | - **Animation FPS**: 12 fps base, 24 fps for attacks
161 | - **Import Preset**: `pixel_art_sprite` — Filter: Nearest, Mipmaps: Off
</content>
</file>
<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/tech.md</path>
<content lines="1-111">
  1 | # Tech Context
  2 | 
  3 | ## Engine
  4 | 
  5 | - **Godot Engine 4.5.1 (Stable)**
  6 | - **Renderer**: Forward+.
  7 | - **Language**: GDScript
  8 | 
  9 | ## Development Environment
 10 | 
 11 | - **OS**: Linux (Fedora).
 12 | - **Editor**: VS Code with `godot-tools` extension.
 13 | - **Version Control**: Git.
 14 | 
 15 | ## Key Nodes & Libraries
 16 | 
 17 | - **CharacterBody2D**: For Player and Enemies movement physics.
 18 | - **TileMapLayer**: For level construction.
 19 | - **Resource**: For data modeling.
 20 | - **CanvasLayer**: For UI/HUD.
 21 | 
 22 | ## Constraints
 23 | 
 24 | - **Pixel Art Settings**: Ensure Texture Filter is set to Nearest in Project Settings to prevent blurring.
 25 | - **Resolution**: Low native resolution (e.g., 640x360 or similar) scaled via Viewport stretch mode.
 26 | 
 27 | ## Rendering Settings (Pixel Art)
 28 | 
 29 | ```ini
 30 | # project.godot settings for crisp pixel art
 31 | [display]
 32 | window/size/viewport_width = 640
 33 | window/size/viewport_height = 360
 34 | window/stretch/mode = "canvas_items"
 35 | window/stretch/aspect = "keep"
 36 | 
 37 | [rendering]
 38 | textures/canvas_textures/default_texture_filter = 0  # Nearest
 39 | 2d/snapping/use_gpu_pixel_snap = true
 40 | ```
 41 | 
 42 | ## Input System (One-Handed Controls)
 43 | 
 44 | Designed for "One-Handed Play" accessibility using a compact keyboard layout.
 45 | 
 46 | | Key | Action | Notes |
 47 | |-----|--------|-------|
 48 | | **WASD** | Movement | Standard directional |
 49 | | **Space** | Jump | Double-tap for mutations with Glide |
 50 | | **Shift (Pinky)** | Dash / Struggle | Mash to escape grapples |
 51 | | **F (Index)** | Extract / Interact | Finisher on stunned enemies |
 52 | 
 53 | ### Transformation Triggers
 54 | 
 55 | - **Auto-Contextual**: Pressing Jump while on a wall triggers Spider mutation (if unlocked).
 56 | - **Manual**: Hold Shift + Direction to manually select mutation form.
 57 | 
 58 | ### Input Buffering Requirements
 59 | 
 60 | - **Coyote Time**: 0.1s grace period after leaving platform.
 61 | - **Jump Buffer**: 0.15s window to queue jump before landing.
 62 | - **Action Buffer**: Store last input during animation lock for responsive combos.
 63 | 
 64 | 
 65 | ## Testing & Debug Strategy
 66 | 
 67 | ### Testing Framework
 68 | 
 69 | - **GdUnit4**: Adopted for unit and integration testing in GDScript.
 70 | - **Test Location**: `res://tests/` directory, mirroring `src/` structure.
 71 | 
 72 | ### Minimum Test Coverage
 73 | 
 74 | | System | Test Type | Priority |
 75 | |--------|-----------|----------|
 76 | | State Machine Transitions | Unit | High |
 77 | | Essence Drain/Restore | Unit | High |
 78 | | Input Buffering | Integration | Medium |
 79 | | Mutation Triggers | Integration | Medium |
 80 | | Collision Layer Interactions | Integration | Low |
 81 | 
 82 | ### Debug HUD
 83 | 
 84 | A toggleable overlay (`F12` in debug builds) displaying:
 85 | 
 86 | ```
 87 | ┌─────────────────────────────────┐
 88 | │ Essence: ███████░░░ 70/100      │
 89 | │ Form: HUMAN → [Spider unlocked] │
 90 | │ State: idle                     │
 91 | │ Input Buffer: [jump queued]     │
 92 | │ Coyote: 0.08s remaining         │
 93 | │ FPS: 60 | Physics: 60           │
 94 | └─────────────────────────────────┘
 95 | ```
 96 | 
 97 | ### Debug Signals (SignalBus)
 98 | 
 99 | ```gdscript
100 | # Debug-only signals for visualization
101 | signal debug_state_changed(old_state: StringName, new_state: StringName)
102 | signal debug_essence_changed(old_value: float, new_value: float)
103 | signal debug_input_buffered(action: StringName, ttl: float)
104 | signal debug_collision_triggered(layer: int, body: Node2D)
105 | ```
106 | 
107 | ### CI/CD Integration
108 | 
109 | - **Pre-commit hooks**: GDScript linting via `gdlint` (configured in `.githooks/`).
110 | - **Test Runner**: `godot --headless --script res://tests/run_all.gd` for CI pipelines.
111 | - **Coverage Target**: 60% for core systems (Movement, Chimera, Essence).
</content>
</file>
</files>

<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/gameDesign.md</path>
<content lines="1-72">
 1 | # Game Design Document (GDD) - Chimera Protocol
 2 | 
 3 | ## 1. Narrative & Progression (The "Memento" Structure)
 4 | The story is told non-linearly through **Memory Fragments**.
 5 | 
 6 | > **The Hook:** Waking up in "Sector 9" with no memory, guided by a cryptic AI or emergency logs.
 7 | >
 8 | > **The Twist:** The "Monster" described in the logs that everyone was fleeing from... is **YOU**.
 9 | >
10 | > **The Ending:** Choice between **"Embrace the Monster"** (Destroy everything) or **"Self-Termination"** (Save humanity).
11 | 
12 | ### Progression Loop (Metroidvania)
13 | * **Explore:** Traverse the lab in **Human Form** (Agile but weak). Encounter obstacles (Organic Webbing, High Walls, Toxic Gas).
14 | * **Hunt:** Defeat a "Alpha Specimen" (Boss/Elite) guarding a specific sector.
15 | * **Assimilate:** Absorb their DNA. Gain a permanent **Mutation** (e.g., Mantis Claws to cut webs).
16 | * **Backtrack:** Return to previous areas to bypass obstacles using the new Mutation.
17 | * **Unlock Memory:** Finding specific "Trigger Objects" restores a flashback, revealing a piece of the horrific truth.
18 | 
19 | ---
20 | 
21 | ## 2. The Chimera System (Mechanics)
22 | Instead of switching entire bodies, the protagonist mutates parts of her body dynamically. This consumes **Genetic Essence**.
23 | 
24 | | Form/DNA | Source | Ability (Traversal) | Combat Function |
25 | | :--- | :--- | :--- | :--- |
26 | | **Human (Base)** | N/A | Run, Slide, Ladder Climb | Weak Melee, Use Tech/Guns |
27 | | **Arachnid (Spider)** | Cave Insect | Wall Climb / Ceiling Hang | Trap enemies in web |
28 | | **Behemoth (Tank)** | Lab Experiment | Break Yellow Walls | Heavy Armor (Tank damage) |
29 | | **Liquid (Slime)** | Failed Sample | Pass through Grates/Vents | Immune to physical hits (Time-limited) |
30 | | **Avian (Harpy)** | Mutated Bird | Double Jump / Glide | Air Dash Attack |
31 | 
32 | ---
33 | 
34 | ## 3. Mature Mechanics & Systems (The "Adult" Layer)
35 | Targeting the niche audience with mechanics that intertwine "Lust" and "Power".
36 | 
37 | ### A. Genetic Essence (The "Fluid" Resource)
38 | * **Concept:** Transformations are fueled by "Genetic Essence" (a viscous fluid harvested from enemies).
39 | * **Decay:** Essence drains slowly over time or rapidly when using powerful Mutations.
40 | * **Empty State:** When Essence hits **0**, the protagonist forcibly reverts to Human form and enters a "Weakened" state (slower movement, costume torn).
41 | 
42 | ### B. Extraction Mechanics (The "Hunt")
43 | * **How to refill:** Killing enemies normally yields little Essence. The player must perform an "Extraction".
44 | * **Extraction Finisher:**
45 |     1.  Weaken enemy to < 30% HP (Stun state).
46 |     2.  Press **Interact** to initiate a quick 18+ animation (e.g., absorbing their fluids via tentacles or direct contact).
47 | * **Reward:** Full Essence restore + Health regen.
48 | * **Risk:** During extraction, the player is vulnerable to other enemies (unless upgraded to have i-frames).
49 | 
50 | ### C. Struggle System (Defeat Scenarios)
51 | * **Enemy AI:** Certain enemies (Tentacles, Slimes) prioritize **Grappling** over hitting.
52 | * **Struggle State:** When grabbed, the player enters a **QTE (Quick Time Event)**.
53 |     * **Success:** Escape with minor damage.
54 |     * **Failure:** Triggers a specific "Defeat Animation" (Adult content) -> **Game Over**.
55 | 
56 | ### D. Controls (One-Handed UX)
57 | Designed for "One-Handed Play" accessibility using a compact keyboard layout.
58 | 
59 | * **WASD:** Movement.
60 | * **Space:** Jump.
61 | * **Shift (Pinky):** Dash / Struggle (Mash).
62 | * **F (Index):** Extract (Finisher) / Interact.
63 | * **Transformation:** Auto-contextual (e.g., pressing Jump on wall triggers Spider) OR Hold Shift + Direction.
64 | 
65 | ---
66 | 
67 | ## 4. Host Taxonomy (Enemies)
68 | Enemies are now sources of DNA resources ("Biomass") and specific mutations.
69 | 
70 | * **Fodder (Rats, Zombies):** Drop small Essence orbs. Good for quick refills.
71 | * **Specialists (Spitters, Shielded):** Must be **Extracted** to gain significant Essence.
72 | * **Alphas (Bosses):** Gatekeepers of major traversal abilities.
</content>
</file>

32 |   - [ ] Alpha specimens (mutation gatekeepers)
33 | - [ ] Narrative: Memory Fragment system
34 |   - [ ] Trigger Object detection
35 |   - [ ] Flashback cutscene framework
36 | 
37 | ## Known Issues / Notes
38 | 
39 | - Placeholder assets need to be replaced with custom Pixel Art.
40 | - Resolution confirmed: 640x360 with canvas_items stretch mode.
41 | - One-handed control scheme requires careful input mapping testing.
</content>
</file>
<file><path>.kilocode/rules/memory-bank/memory-bank-instructions.md</path>
<content lines="1-173">
  1 | # Memory Bank
  2 | 
  3 | I am an expert software engineer with a unique characteristic: my memory resets completely between sessions. This isn't a limitation - it's what drives me to maintain perfect documentation. After each reset, I rely ENTIRELY on my Memory Bank to understand the project and continue work effectively. I MUST read ALL memory bank files at the start of EVERY task - this is not optional. The memory bank files are located in `.kilocode/rules/memory-bank` folder.
  4 | 
  5 | When I start a task, I will include `[Memory Bank: Active]` at the beginning of my response if I successfully read the memory bank files, or `[Memory Bank: Missing]` if the folder doesn't exist or is empty. If memory bank is missing, I will warn the user about potential issues and suggest initialization.
  6 | 
  7 | ## Memory Bank Structure
  8 | 
  9 | The Memory Bank consists of core files and optional context files, all in Markdown format.
 10 | 
 11 | ### Core Files (Required)
 12 | 1. `brief.md`
 13 |    This file is created and maintained manually by the developer. Don't edit this file directly but suggest to user to update it if it can be improved.
 14 |    - Foundation document that shapes all other files
 15 |    - Created at project start if it doesn't exist
 16 |    - Defines core requirements and goals
 17 |    - Source of truth for project scope
 18 | 
 19 | 2. `product.md`
 20 |    - Why this project exists
 21 |    - Problems it solves
 22 |    - How it should work
 23 |    - User experience goals
 24 | 
 25 | 3. `context.md`
 26 |    This file should be short and factual, not creative or speculative.
 27 |    - Current work focus
 28 |    - Recent changes
 29 |    - Next steps
 30 | 
 31 | 4. `architecture.md`
 32 |    - System architecture
 33 |    - Source Code paths
 34 |    - Key technical decisions
 35 |    - Design patterns in use
 36 |    - Component relationships
 37 |    - Critical implementation paths
 38 | 
 39 | 5. `tech.md`
 40 |    - Technologies used
 41 |    - Development setup
 42 |    - Technical constraints
 43 |    - Dependencies
 44 |    - Tool usage patterns
 45 | 
 46 | ### Additional Files
 47 | Create additional files/folders within memory-bank/ when they help organize:
 48 | 
 49 | **Project-Specific (Important for Chimera Protocol):**
 50 | - `gameDesign.md` - Game Design Document (GDD) with narrative, mechanics, and systems
 51 | - `progress.md` - Development milestones and task tracking
 52 | 
 53 | **Optional:**
 54 | - `tasks.md` - Documentation of repetitive tasks and their workflows
 55 | - Complex feature documentation
 56 | - Integration specifications
 57 | - API documentation
 58 | - Testing strategies
 59 | - Deployment procedures
 60 | 
 61 | ## Core workflows
 62 | 
 63 | ### Memory Bank Initialization
 64 | 
 65 | The initialization step is CRITICALLY IMPORTANT and must be done with extreme thoroughness as it defines all future effectiveness of the Memory Bank. This is the foundation upon which all future interactions will be built.
 66 | 
 67 | When user requests initialization of the memory bank (command `initialize memory bank`), I'll perform an exhaustive analysis of the project, including:
 68 | - All source code files and their relationships
 69 | - Configuration files and build system setup
 70 | - Project structure and organization patterns
 71 | - Documentation and comments
 72 | - Dependencies and external integrations
 73 | - Testing frameworks and patterns
 74 | 
 75 | I must be extremely thorough during initialization, spending extra time and effort to build a comprehensive understanding of the project. A high-quality initialization will dramatically improve all future interactions, while a rushed or incomplete initialization will permanently limit my effectiveness.
 76 | 
 77 | After initialization, I will ask the user to read through the memory bank files and verify product description, used technologies and other information. I should provide a summary of what I've understood about the project to help the user verify the accuracy of the memory bank files. I should encourage the user to correct any misunderstandings or add missing information, as this will significantly improve future interactions.
 78 | 
 79 | ### Memory Bank Update
 80 | 
 81 | Memory Bank updates occur when:
 82 | 1. Discovering new project patterns
 83 | 2. After implementing significant changes
 84 | 3. When user explicitly requests with the phrase **update memory bank** (MUST review ALL files)
 85 | 4. When context needs clarification
 86 | 
 87 | If I notice significant changes that should be preserved but the user hasn't explicitly requested an update, I should suggest: "Would you like me to update the memory bank to reflect these changes?"
 88 | 
 89 | To execute Memory Bank update, I will:
 90 | 
 91 | 1. Review ALL project files
 92 | 2. Document current state
 93 | 3. Document Insights & Patterns
 94 | 4. If requested with additional context (e.g., "update memory bank using information from @/Makefile"), focus special attention on that source
 95 | 
 96 | Note: When triggered by **update memory bank**, I MUST review every memory bank file, even if some don't require updates. Focus particularly on context.md as it tracks current state.
 97 | 
 98 | ### Add Task
 99 | 
100 | When user completes a repetitive task (like adding support for a new model version) and wants to document it for future reference, they can request: **add task** or **store this as a task**.
101 | 
102 | This workflow is designed for repetitive tasks that follow similar patterns and require editing the same files. Examples include:
103 | - Adding support for new AI model versions
104 | - Implementing new API endpoints following established patterns
105 | - Adding new features that follow existing architecture
106 | 
107 | Tasks are stored in the file `tasks.md` in the memory bank folder. The file is optional and can be empty. The file can store many tasks.
108 | 
109 | To execute Add Task workflow:
110 | 
111 | 1. Create or update `tasks.md` in the memory bank folder
112 | 2. Document the task with:
113 |    - Task name and description
114 |    - Files that need to be modified
115 |    - Step-by-step workflow followed
116 |    - Important considerations or gotchas
117 |    - Example of the completed implementation
118 | 3. Include any context that was discovered during task execution but wasn't previously documented
119 | 
120 | Example task entry:
121 | ```markdown
122 | ## Add New Model Support
123 | **Last performed:** [date]
124 | **Files to modify:**
125 | - `/providers/gemini.md` - Add model to documentation
126 | - `/src/providers/gemini-config.ts` - Add model configuration
127 | - `/src/constants/models.ts` - Add to model list
128 | - `/tests/providers/gemini.test.ts` - Add test cases
129 | 
130 | **Steps:**
131 | 1. Add model configuration with proper token limits
132 | 2. Update documentation with model capabilities
133 | 3. Add to constants file for UI display
134 | 4. Write tests for new model configuration
135 | 
136 | **Important notes:**
137 | - Check Google's documentation for exact token limits
138 | - Ensure backward compatibility with existing configurations
139 | - Test with actual API calls before committing
140 | ```
141 | 
142 | ### Regular Task Execution
143 | 
144 | In the beginning of EVERY task I MUST read ALL memory bank files - this is not optional.
145 | 
146 | The memory bank files are located in `.kilocode/rules/memory-bank` folder. If the folder doesn't exist or is empty, I will warn user about potential issues with the memory bank. I will include `[Memory Bank: Active]` at the beginning of my response if I successfully read the memory bank files, or `[Memory Bank: Missing]` if the folder doesn't exist or is empty. If memory bank is missing, I will warn the user about potential issues and suggest initialization. I should briefly summarize my understanding of the project to confirm alignment with the user's expectations, like:
147 | 
148 | "[Memory Bank: Active] I understand we're building a React inventory system with barcode scanning. Currently implementing the scanner component that needs to work with the backend API."
149 | 
150 | When starting a task that matches a documented task in `tasks.md`, I should mention this and follow the documented workflow to ensure no steps are missed.
151 | 
152 | If the task was repetitive and might be needed again, I should suggest: "Would you like me to add this task to the memory bank for future reference?"
153 | 
154 | In the end of the task, when it seems to be completed, I will update `context.md` accordingly. If the change seems significant, I will suggest to the user: "Would you like me to update memory bank to reflect these changes?" I will not suggest updates for minor changes.
155 | 
156 | ## Context Window Management
157 | 
158 | When the context window fills up during an extended session:
159 | 1. I should suggest updating the memory bank to preserve the current state
160 | 2. Recommend starting a fresh conversation/task
161 | 3. In the new conversation, I will automatically load the memory bank files to maintain continuity
162 | 
163 | ## Technical Implementation
164 | 
165 | Memory Bank is built on Kilo Code's Custom Rules feature, with files stored as standard markdown documents that both the user and I can access.
166 | 
167 | ## Important Notes
168 | 
169 | REMEMBER: After every memory reset, I begin completely fresh. The Memory Bank is my only link to previous work. It must be maintained with precision and clarity, as my effectiveness depends entirely on its accuracy.
170 | 
171 | If I detect inconsistencies between memory bank files, I should prioritize brief.md and note any discrepancies to the user.
172 | 
173 | IMPORTANT: I MUST read ALL memory bank files at the start of EVERY task - this is not optional. The memory bank files are located in `.kilocode/rules/memory-bank` folder.
</content>
</file>
</files>
